Award.AbstractNarration:
0844850
Christine Julien
University of Texas at Austin
CAREER: Opportunistic Middleware for Delay-Tolerant Networks

Delay-tolerant networks are characterized by extreme unpredictability of connectivity due to disconnections between senders and receivers that often persist for long periods of time. This style of network has become increasingly important, largely due to emerging applications, such as enabling access to the Internet in remote areas, social networking, and mobile search and rescue. Existing solutions are generally tailored to very specific applications, instead of focusing on application properties in general.

Intellectual Merit. This project uses applications' common characteristics to drive the development of coordination support for delay-tolerant networks by simplifying application development and providing an expressiveness that enables new classes of fluid and responsive applications. The project begins by developing an understanding of coordination in delay-tolerant networks by developing a theory of temporally extended conversations among communicating parties. To support these conversations, the research also examines the creation of new communication protocols that adapt their behavior in response to changing conditions, enabling the communication infrastructure to continue to meet applications' requirements, even as the network's operating conditions change. To support this adaptation, the project develops new notions of context-awareness, or the ability to collect and interpret information about an application's environment. The project ties these three components together to create an adaptive middleware for delay-tolerant networks that provides a software support system that enables application developers to use simple constructs to create expressive coordinating applications.

Broader Impact. The project includes an education agenda that relies on these tangible applications for delay-tolerant networks to increase the accessibility of mobile computing to students and the public through hands-on demonstrations and course projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project spanned multiple years of our work on supporting "conversations" in delay-tolerant networks (DTNs). In DTNs, devices experience only intermittent connectivity with one another. We built the MadMAN middleware, which allows conversations to be maintained over disconnections and transitioned from one communication medium to another. We also built the MadApp application development framework, which enables a programmer to divide a conversation into two components: a "small" component that can be delivered over an expensive but high bandwidth and low latency communication vector and a "large" component that can be delivered more slowly over a low cost, but low bandwidth and high latency link. The developer can then build a web application, specifying how all of the application's content is allocated to each of these conversational components. We evaluated our contributions through a variety of simulations, emulations, testbed experiments, and deployed applications. The MadMAN middleware was evaluated on top of our Pharos robotic testbed. We deployed the middleware to a fleet of robots that moved in and out of one anothers' connectivity and demonstrated how the middleware transferred connections. We also built multiple applications (on the Android operating system) to demonstrate the contributions. We have written our software to be directly incorporated into widely adopted and employed delay-tolerant network middleware, and we have demonstrated the integration. This has significant impact on the DTN community. We have highlighted important novel uses of context information in the DTN domain and in search in pervasive computing more generally. These pave the way for additional contributions in the principal disciplines of the project. Further, a primary goal of the project has been to engage undergraduate students in supervised research. The undergraduate student who is the primary undergraduate researcher on this project has been tightly woven into the research project and now leads projects on his own (and has presented his research at three international conferences, supported by this project). The project's targeted outreach efforts further engage the K-12 community in central Texas, hopefully exposing and encouraging a new generation of STEM researchers.
